mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Structure and Function Studies of Methylation and Pseudouridylation on Ribosome Biogenesis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Eukaryotic cells employ a sophisticated process to generate properly assembledribosomes. This intricate process commences in the nucleolus through the transcription of a singular 35S ribosomal RNA precursor (pre-rRNA), encompassing three distinct rRNAs (5.8S, 18S, and 25S), along with the 5' and 3' externally or internally transcribed spacer regions (5'-ETS, 3'-ETS, ITS1, and ITS2). Approximately 2% of rRNA nucleotides undergo 12 of the 140 recognized types of RNA modifications (Sharma and Lafontaine, 2015; Sloan et al., 2017).Among the most prevalent modifications of rRNA are 2'-O-methylation and pseudouridylation, both facilitated by small nucleolar ribonucleoparticles (snoRNPs). The box C/D snoRNPs play a pivotal role in the site-specific addition of 2'-O-methyl groups at 80-100 sites in rRNA, while the box H/ACA snoRNPs are responsible for the isomerization of a similar number of uridines. Each snoRNP comprises a catalytic subunit, with fibrillarin serving as the methyltransferase and Cbf5 as the pseudouridine synthase in yeast, respectively1 . There are still many unanswered questions to be explored for the function of 2'-Omethylation and pseudouridylation. The impact of rRNA modification is mainly concentrated on the assembly of ribosome precursors (such as 90S pre-ribosome) and the protein synthesis process of mature ribosomes. Therefore, by studying the structural and functional changes of pre-ribosome and mature ribosome caused by loss of modification, we can understand the regulatory roles of the RNA backbone modification. This dissertation uses structural and functional studies to shed light on the intricate mechanisms of the regulatory roles of the RNA backbone modification. In Chapter 1, we showed that removal of chaperones for box C/D snoRNP can potentially alter the dynamics of 90S pre-ribosome of which the U3 box C/D snoRNP forms the core and thus allow us the capture of transiently associated factors. Our structure model provides the first near atomic model of the yeast Bfr2-Lcp5 complex. And I proved the model with the protein-protein interaction results and the secondary structures of recombinant Bfr2 and Bfr2-Lcp5 complex obtained by Circular Dichroism. Chapters 2 of this dissertation details unpresented views of ribosomes as they function and assemble in absence of 2'-O-methylation. For the first time, I - 8 - extensively surveyed the growth sensitivity of cells that lack 2'-O-methylation to translation inhibitors, revealing a dependence of inhibition on temperature. In Chapter 3, I further compared melting temperatures of the healthy and the hypomodified ribosomes by Circular Dichroism and showed a significant decrease in thermal stability in absence of chemical modifications, underscoring their pivotal roles in determining ribosome stability and possibly its sensitivity to translation inhibitors. I pioneered the study of the effects of translation inhibitors on ribosome stability using Circular Dichroism. Finally, our lab obtained the structure of a hypopseudouridylated ribosome bound with a aminoglycoside (hygromycin B), which revealed a possibility mechanism for its hypersensivity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Hong Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hengli Tang, University Representative; Robert Silvers, Committee Member; Qing-Xiang Sang, Committee Member.
